item.title: [HTTPCORE-601] SSLIOSession.close() is never called for async server handling HTTP1
item.description:
On 5.0, an asynchronous server handling an HTTP1 request never calls SSLIOSession.close(). The attached sample server program exhibits the problem. To test:

  1. Set a breakpoint in SSLIOSession.close().
  2. Make some requests.

The expectation is for the breakpoint to be triggered when the connection ends. The observed behavior is that the breakpoint is never reached.

The sample program uses Conscrypt (org.conscrypt:conscrypt-openjdk-uber:2.2.1) but the root problem occurs with any JSSE provider including the default. There is an additional bad side effect with Conscrypt, however, which is that the program spins in the selection loop and consumes excessive CPU.

When AbstractHttp1StreamDuplexer.requestShutdown() sets OP_WRITE, this code in onOutput() should call SSLIOSession.close():

https://github.com/apache/httpcomponents-core/blob/44cab548cb4e15d56235aa12eaf0898d028351d0/httpcore5/src/main/java/org/apache/hc/core5/http/impl/nio/AbstractHttp1StreamDuplexer.java#L366-L373

This doesn't happen because SSLIOSession.isAppOutputReady() returns false here:

https://github.com/apache/httpcomponents-core/blob/44cab548cb4e15d56235aa12eaf0898d028351d0/httpcore5/src/main/java/org/apache/hc/core5/reactor/InternalDataChannel.java#L139

which happens because status is CLOSING and sslEngine.getHandshakeStatus() returns NEED_WRAP. So onOutput() is not called after requestShutdown() and OP_WRITE remains set. On Conscrypt, selection on OP_WRITE keeps succeeding which causes the spin.

I tried hacking SSLIOSession.isAppOutputReady():
— a/httpcore5/src/main/java/org/apache/hc/core5/reactor/ssl/SSLIOSession.java
+++ b/httpcore5/src/main/java/org/apache/hc/core5/reactor/ssl/SSLIOSession.java
@@ -523,8 +523,9 @@ public boolean isAppOutputReady() throws IOException {
         this.session.getLock().lock();
         try

{              return (this.appEventMask & SelectionKey.OP_WRITE) > 0 -                    && this.status == ACTIVE -                    && this.sslEngine.getHandshakeStatus() == HandshakeStatus.NOT_HANDSHAKING; +                    && ((this.status == ACTIVE +                         && this.sslEngine.getHandshakeStatus() == HandshakeStatus.NOT_HANDSHAKING) +                        || this.status == CLOSING);          }

finally

{              this.session.getLock().unlock();          }

This is probably not the appropriate fix, but it does call SSLIOSession.close() and does not spin with Conscrypt so something that achieves that should work.

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment:
rhashimoto I was able to reproduce the issue with Conscrypt 2.2.1 but not with Conscrypt 1.4.2 or any Oracle JSSE providers (tried Java 1.8 and Java 11.0.3).

At the moment this looks to me very much like a bug in Conscrypt 2.2.1.

What is happening is this:

  1. The client closes the session on its end after having executed the entire message exchange
  2. #updateEventMask detects the end of stream from the opposite endpoint and puts the session into the CLOSING state.
  3. #updateEventMask detects that the session is in the CLOSING state and there is no more outgoing data and closes outbound stream with SSLEngine#closeOutbound()
  4. The Conscrypt engine however does not seem to react to this method. It still returns false from SSLEngine#isOutboundDone() but also remains in the NOT_HANDSHAKING state, which does make any sense to me and looks wrong.
  5. The session loops forever waiting for the SSL engine either to report outbound stream as done or start handshaking.

I will debug Conscrypt code before reaching any conclusion and would also see if there is a reasonable defensive strategy against such behavior.

What I do not understand is why you think that SSLIOSession#close() never getting called is a problem. The SSLIOSession is supposed to shut down itself if the opposite endpoint closes the session on its end.

Please comment.

Oleg

What I do not understand is why you think that SSLIOSession#close() never getting called is a problem.

I just assumed that because in most Java APIs I've used, a close() method is meant to be called and it is a red flag to me when it isn't. So I guess that's a bad assumption on my part.

I do see AbstractHttp1StreamDuplexer#requestShutdown() being called from here:

https://github.com/apache/httpcomponents-core/blob/44cab548cb4e15d56235aa12eaf0898d028351d0/httpcore5/src/main/java/org/apache/hc/core5/http/impl/nio/AbstractHttp1StreamDuplexer.java#L291

Is that not supposed to initiate session closure from the server side? Under what conditions would this code be reached:

https://github.com/apache/httpcomponents-core/blob/44cab548cb4e15d56235aa12eaf0898d028351d0/httpcore5/src/main/java/org/apache/hc/core5/http/impl/nio/AbstractHttp1StreamDuplexer.java#L366-L373

rhashimoto In HTTP/1.1 protocol the server endpoints rarely initiate connection shutdown unless explicitly requested by the client endpoint with Connection: close request header. Server endpoints execute message exchanges and then keep the connection alive for a period of time defined by their keep-alive setting expecting the client endpoints to re-use the same connection for subsequent requests. Connections more commonly get closed by the client, in which case SSLSession#close() method may never get called by the server explicitly.

Oleg

olegk I think an important exception to this rule is certain HTTP errors which leave the connection unusable, such as 408 Request Timeout and 413 Payload Too Large. The server has to initiate a connection close after returning one of these errors, simply because the connection is no longer in any valid protocol state.
I see (I think). And what are the semantics of AbstractHttp1StreamDuplexer#requestShutdown() when called from onInput()?

rhashimoto

And what are the semantics of AbstractHttp1StreamDuplexer#requestShutdown() when called from onInput()?

This is exactly the point when the client half-closes the connection immediately after or in the middle of a message exchange. This, however, rarely applies to well behaved TLS sessions as connection shutdown in TLS is signaled with a notify handshake.

Oleg

rhashimoto The spin in the session looks very much like a defect in ConscryptEngine. In the #isisOutboundDone method [1] the session state is STATE_CLOSED but pendingOutboundEncryptedBytes method returns 139739177586008L. looks unrealistic and pretty random too me.

I am tempted to close this issue as `Not a Problem`. I would nice if someone had time and inclination to report the issue to Conscrypt developers. In the meantime I will try to find a work-around for this mis-behavior.

Oleg

[1] https://github.com/google/conscrypt/blob/2.2.1/common/src/main/java/org/conscrypt/ConscryptEngine.java#L653

rhashimoto PR with proposed work-around:

https://github.com/apache/httpcomponents-core/pull/149

Oleg

I confirm that the PR eliminates the spin when using Conscrypt.

However, I never saw ConscryptEngine#pendingOutboundEncryptedBytes() returning a bogus value. When the spin happens for me it is returning 31. I am testing my sample program with a curl request:

curl -k -v --http1.1 https://localhost:8080/

Also I always see AbstractHttp1StreamDuplexer#requestShutdown() being called, both with Conscrypt and with the default provider. It sounds like you're saying I should generally not expect to see this, is that correct?

rhashimoto I re-checked my findings and found out I had made a mistake. There is indeed 31 bytes still stuck in the ConscryptEngine after SSLEngine#closeOutbound() call for some reason. I will try to find out why.

Oleg
rhashimoto I came up with a better work-around, though I am now pretty convinced this is a bug in Conscrypt 2.2.1. Please review / re-test.
Still no spinning at the latest commit. pendingOutboundEncryptedBytes() now goes to 0.
